prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong. The situation involves a couple where the husband works from home and set up his office in their bedroom despite being offered the basement. The wife feels it's causing her a lot of disruption because she has to manage the kids, housework, and her own job. She told him she can't guarantee silence if he's in the bedroom, leading to their argument.

First, I need to consider both sides. The husband chose the bedroom despite the basement being an option. His job involves a lot of conference calls, so he might prefer a better view, but that's a personal preference. The wife is handling most of the household and work responsibilities. If he's in the bedroom, it restricts her movement and ability to take care of things. 

The key points are: the husband made a choice that affects the wife's daily life, and she's trying to communicate her needs. The wife is trying to set boundaries by suggesting the basement. It's about shared space and mutual respect. 

From a fairness standpoint, when someone sets up an office in a shared space, they should consider how it impacts others. The husband's choice to work in the bedroom is causing her inconvenience. The wife is asserting her right to use the space as well. 

The question is whether she's wrong for not keeping him undisturbed. She's not the one causing the disruption; he is. She's trying to manage the situation but can't fully control others (like the kids) in the bedroom area. So, her stance is about setting limits and communicating her needs. 

In relationships, compromise is important. The husband could have prioritized the basement for her sake, even if the view is better. The wife isn't the one making the demands without reason; she's the one dealing with the consequences of his choice. Therefore, the husband might be the one in the wrong for not considering her situation. 

So the answer would be B (No, the author is not in the wrong).
